displayed_text: Family Member: Oh that’s not too bad. Doctor: Yeah it’s not too bad. And the pill you take, there's a funky schedule but normally it's like, twice a day. But not every day. And there's a set schedule. You don't have to be here every day for that. But I think the follow up there is once every four weeks if I'm not wrong. Family Member: The pill isn't in the container? He has to come down here? Doctor: Well, we give it to you. But it's a funky formulation where, because you know, we do an oral formulation of the chemo is a challenge. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So this is like, there's a loading dose and then you have a little bit of another dose. So it's like, it's a pharma-pharmaco kinetics dream, who thought about it, which is not like a doctor dream, which is like, “just give me the pill in my pocket once a day.” I think eventually they're going to do that. But there is a funky schedule to it. None of which you have to be here, you know, the entire time. But I think in the first few- oh gosh, the first few days I think that you're here maybe for the first week every day. So, but I'll get the schedule right, but once you get on a flow, you're not here every day. Not even close. So it’s either once every three weeks, or once every four weeks. Patient: I can do it because obviously the Xtandi has run its course. Family Member: You don't know yet if you want to do the trial. Patient: If I do the trial. I take what they give me. Family Member: Oh, that's right. Doctor: Yeah there's no choice there. Family Member: So if he wants to go somewhere, what’s the longest period of time he can be gone? Doctor: Oh. Well, probably three or four weeks

Patient: Okay. Question. Sixteen to seventeen, and I don’t know the time frame that it went from sixteen to seventeen, but in (cell phone rings) Doctor: Yeah, don’t read much into it. You know, we’re just checking it more often. Patient: Well, I understand that, but what does that mean to the aggressiveness of the cancer? Does it - Doctor: Okay. Yeah, I mean my sense is that people who, let’s - I don’t have prostate cancer that I know of right now - but, if my PSA was going up and I don’t have the diagnosis, it sort of tells me if it’s going up that fast that I’m more likely when I put a needle in it to find bad cancer. So, we already know you’ve got bad cancer. Patient: Yeah. So, this is, doesn’t tell you. Doctor: Doesn’t tell you. Patient: Then, why do I keep getting stuck? Doctor: Uh, because - Doctor: You know, we’re about ready to start, you know, a trial or a drug, uh, you know, so, Patient: So, you need that base, a current baseline? Doctor: Yeah, we wanna know where you are as we get started. Patient: And that’s understandable. Doctor: It’s your turn. I want you to do that for me.

Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: Oh, and, let me not forget that you’re also a candidate for a study called, Iron Man. Family Member: Hum. Doctor: Which is an international study where you would there donate once a year a tube of blood, or is it two? Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: And you fill out questionnaires to share with people about your journey. You know? How is this helping? Not helping? What don’t you like? Family Member: Oh. Doctor: I fill stuff out, too. And then we get all this data together- Family Member: Right. Doctor: - so that people in Brazil and Australia, and, you know, Ireland, all go and answer the same set of questionnaires. So it’s really fascinating because there’s a lot of people like you just all around the world. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Anyway, so, we want you to pony up to that, too. So if that’s not enough to overwhelm you, um, let me know. I can always do more. Patient: Okay. I just need somebody to send me like ah-

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the last 2 years (1 year but less: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the last 2 years (1 year but less than 2 years ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.3 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::3 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Family Member: Period. Doctor: It’s still better than having to use a walker otherwise. So that’s… Family Member: I’m not walking outside with that cane. That’s what you told me last week. And I said alright just go ahead and fall because I’m not coming out to get you. I don’t want to see you hurt that’s why I think preventive measures Doctor: A fracture now would really set us back. So- Family Member: Yes because we have brittle bones. Doctor: And I might put in for a bone strengthening medication just so you know it starts, uh it’s an injection. So if he can get it authorized and all that we might as well start it about every few months we’ll have to do it, so not that often. Family Member: I’m not opposed to that. Anything that will help J___ - Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: -and keep him from harm. Doctor: Yep. Family Member: Because we’re doing Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: a little bit better

Patient: I haven't gotten, gotten down to that. Doctor: Oh, are you reading the consent? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Yeah, so you know what I mean. Doctor: Mmm. Didn’t they give you a bigger version before you go blind looking at your phone, because it's like 30 pages of that stuff- Patient: Yeah, yeah. Doctor: You want us to print it? Patient: Seven to twenty nine. Doctor: Yeah, it is, it is a mess. Patient: I haven't read it before. Doctor: I mean, most of it is, um, I say usual, you might get tired, because tired is always tops of everything. Patient: Mhm.

Patient: Alright. Doctor: Um, um unless you tell me J____ I know exactly what I want to do I want to go you know one way or the other. Patient: Adverse effects to radiation? (Laughs) Doctor: So radiation, radiation is an additional therapy. Patient: Sure. Doctor: Clearly. It uses thermal energy. Patient: Right. Doctor: Ahh to essentially sterilize the field that exposed to that… Patient: I’m sure it’s very pinpoint because my wife was over at the R ___. So, Doctor: It is, it is as precise as they can make it. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: It’s done you know the modeling that they use, the 3D mapping…

Family Member: Yes, please. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: Oh. When would be – when would we get started? Oh, you said you had to get approval through insurance? Doctor: Right. So we’re good. And K___ does the process. And then they almost map out all the days. Now, one thing that I like is you’re young, and your veins look pretty good. Instead of putting a catheter and all that in- Family Member: Right. Doctor: Which is a big to-do, I’m going to send you over there for an assessment. If they think they can just do it right off. Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: So that’s their new thing. They don’t need the catheter sometimes. Family Member: Oh, good, good. Doctor: You know? If you’re seventy-five, the veins aren’t so hot for it to hold for three hours, two, three hours, but I think with you it might be just fine. Family Member: Would you-? Okay. Doctor: So I think that’s one step where we could possibly save.

Patient: Uh I have to tell Dr. C____, but I’m gonna go for it. Doctor: Okay. Yeah. Patient: I need to make an appointment with him and do the uh. Doctor: For the scope and all that. Patient: Scope. Doctor: So he makes sure the passage is okay and the bladder is safe and all that. Alright so I’ll let them know if you’re okay with it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Okay and uh then we’ll plan for your appointment after the cryo and everything is done. So forget about the June appointment. We’ll just schedule something later on. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay because probably the whole month of June will be taken up so most likely it will be somewhere end of July or so. Okay? Patient: So how do I make the appointment for the scope? Doctor: Yeah I’m gonna tell them so the scheduler will hook you up or J the nurse will talk to the scheduler. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: Sure. Um hum. We can put off the cataract surgery, too. Doctor: Yeah. If he had to. Family Member: But it’s hard to get. Doctor: But for now let’s keep it. Family Member: That’s what I think. We’ve waited a long time. Doctor: Don’t, don’t change anything until we see what the dates fall out to be. Family Member: Fine. Yeah. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And if we have to, we really have to, we will, but I’m going to try and work around these dates. Okay? Patient: Why don’t you let me sign it now so I don’t have to come back? Doctor: Yeah. Yeah. I’m going to have S___ come in and so she can bring the consent in. Okay? Patient: How’s your husband? Doctor: He’s doing well. Thanks for asking. (Laughter)

Patient: So how have you been doing sir? Doctor: I’m doing fine. Patient: Did you, did you - Were you able to recoup? Doctor: Well I’m still trying. Patient: You’re still trying (laughs) Doctor: That’s probably the biggest drawback is the weather, cold weather. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I’ll tell him about you though. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But he’s coming May ninth. Patient: Alright. Don’t you leave me yet man. (Laughs) Doctor: I hope so too. He’s the man right?

Patient: When I was in the hospital checking every day - Doctor: Today your creatinine is one point zero. And your liver tests are all normal. Your PSA is pending; it looks like – Patient: They didn’t know. Doctor: It just hasn’t resulted yet. Family Member: Uh, the last reading when we were here on the twelfth of November, the reading was seventeen for PSA. Did that corrected? Doctor: Seventeen. Family Member: And the scale - is that improving or not or - Patient: Thirty-eight point six or thirty-eight. Family Member: I don’t know Doctor: It was forty-eight in July. Patient: Right. Doctor: And when I saw him on November seventh he had been on the pills for two weeks.

Patient: Which way did it get it? From the left side or right side? Doctor: The biopsy? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Ooh, I want to say left. Uh, I think it was the left, and then they did the special stains underneath the microscope, and, you know, looked for actual prostate stains, and it was positive on both of them. So now the question is, you started your hormone shot back up, and you’ve kind of been on it the whole time. It’s just you were delayed a little bit on one day, one of them, and now it’s you need another medicine. But I want to make sure that you are well healed from your pneumonia before we go ahead and do that. Patient: Yeah. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Probably, you know, another several weeks or so until you feel like you’re back on your feet, uh, and over the flu, the pneumonia, and all that, but we think you’re going to need a set of pills to kind of help keep the prostate in check. Patient: What kind of pills? Doctor: So these are FDA-approved pills called Xtandi, which is the trade name. Uh, they’re four pills once a day, and their primary goal of how they work is it’s, it’s like a big hormone pill again. So it’s to help your shot work better. It also is approved by the FDA because it helps you live longer. No cures. Same as we were before but we need to get a handle on all these things in the lung. In the same way, you’re also a candidate for chemo to tell you the truth. Uh, so chemo’s in the mix as well, but the majority of folks I think, and I’m not saying you do, but my patients tend to prefer pills before going on to chemotherapy, and I think way back when we initially again reconnected you were not in so much favor of chemo, uh, as he’s already shaking his head, but I want to bring that up again because at some point we may need to go to chemo. So I want to put that out there still. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but we do have a set of pills. Now, the good news is every time there’s an approved medication, you know, we’re at K______, so we do a lot of clinical studies. So one of our studies is to use that same medication and see if we add a second pill to half the group whether you’d respond better. So I like that study because it’s all pills and no one gets a placebo when you’re thinking about the Xtandi pills. Everyone is on the regular pill that is approved. The question of the placebo versus the other drug is extra. Okay? So I’m not sure if that makes sense or if you’ve got questions with that, but we’re going to try hard to have you be, you know, considered for that study. Uh, I want you to still recover well from your, your hospitalization, but, uh, but that’s in the works for us to consider. The other part is either way, however we move forward, there’s another study, which is a registry study, called, Iron Man. Uh, not that you become iron man- Patient: Hum. Doctor: but that all your experiences as to what’s happened to you get captured. And that means you write out and answer questionnaires. I write out and answer questionnaires. Uh, and then about once a year we take some blood to see what’s happening uh in terms of new research. Uh, and that participation’s pretty cool because a lot of other men around the world are, are participating. And so we get answers from guys from Australia, Ireland, uh, you know, England uh, gosh, Canada, France, so all of that. So everyone’s experience will be captured. And they’re all like you, in the same boat. So we hope you consider that as well. Uh, but I think what we might do is workup to make sure that you’re eligible for all that stuff. I want to introduce you to M___, who’s our research nurse, uh, who just wants to say hi, and then I think we’ll have you come back in a couple weeks when you feel like you’re a little bit stronger.

Patient: So let me ask you this here, doc. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Do people come out of that surgery? Doctor: Oh, yeah! They do! (Cell phone rings) Patient: Right. Doctor: But it’s a start. So, what does that tell us? It’s aggressive, but we know that about your cancer. But, if we don’t talk about surgery as an option, then we didn’t do right by you because you know that that’s a possibility. What’s the root of all that? Well, it’s your cancer not controlled. That’s always the root of all evil. Not your bones, but your lymph nodes are growing. So, in this – Patient: So what’s goin’ on, so what’s goin’ on with my bones? Doctor: Nothin’. Patient: He just said that somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: No. I didn’t say anything. Patient: The other doctor that came in before him, before Dr. P_, said somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: Oh.

Patient: No. Doctor: And, huh, you’re by yourself today? Patient: Yeah. Um hum. Doctor: Huh, huh, so were you having double vision? Patient: No. But not- Doctor: Just the eye was getting too dry for the blink, it doesn’t blink? Patient: It doesn’t blink. The eye’s not going to blink. But, you know. Doctor: Did they scan your brain or anything? Patient: I did a, I did a, in my, huh, in my, in my eye hit at the Doctor: Because it’s gotten worse. Patient: What? Doctor: I mean, your face is even- Patient: Well, one thing, I said the wrong side. It’s not the right side. It’s the left side.

Patient: So it seems to me though that - Doctor: Yeah? Patient: I come off the Xtandi now; I’m not having, I’m not taking anything to treat the cancer. Doctor: Yeah, right, until you get to the next one, which is this radium or Xofigo. It starts with another “X” name. So don’t get confused. So it’s not Xtandi; it’s Xofigo. Patient: But it would seem to me it makes more sense to keep taking Xtandi till I’m on that treatment. Doctor: You would think so but your cancer has figured it out. (pause) Family Member: So could it start like the first of January and then - Doctor: I mean you could, you know, you could make an arbitrary date like, okay, stop here, but I think you’ll feel better off the medicine that isn’t helping you anymore at this moment. Time to let it go. Patient: What was my PSA? Doctor: Is it back? Healthcare Professional: I don’t know that it is. Doctor: Oh from last time? Healthcare Professional: No, He did it the other day; no, he did it when he did his scans. He did it when he did is scans.
